div.p: hi everyone thank you all so much for
having me tonight it's always cool to be
in a room where I don't know almost
anyone except for David and a few others
but it's nice to get out of the bubble
of politics where everyone already knows
everyone in the room so my name is Jo
Anna Chlumsky I am a communications
strategy consultant and I primarily work
with political candidates elected
officials government agencies advocacy
organizations nonprofits and I'm here
tonight to talk to you about one of my
favorite clients and the client that
probably takes up the most of my time
and has probably taken the most years
off of my life which is the chicago city
council Progressive Caucus the
Progressive Caucus is 11 out of the 50
aldermen so that is twenty-two percent
of the City Council to any math people
did I do that right twenty-two percent i
believe and i started working with the
Progressive Caucus right when it
launched back in 2012 or perhaps early
2013 I had come out of several years of
just working on political campaigns and
an alderman who's part of the
Progressive Caucus alderman Rick munos
of the 22nd ward I don't think we have
any 22nd warders in here tonight little
village Lawndale asked me if I'd like to
help they were getting ready to launch
this new thing at the time there were
eight members that was in 2012-2013
since then we've had a municipal
election as you guys probably remember
the whole Chewie rom situation there
were also 50 alder manic well maybe not
50 there were a few that weren't up for

p.span: reelection but there were also all

div.p: romantic races all over the city back in
2015 and so since that time of the
launch of the Progressive Caucus we've
gone from eight members to 11 which is
actually a pretty a pretty big jump I
was proud to help reelect all the
members of the Progressive Caucus who
ran for re-election in 2015 were
reelected and then we also picked up
four seats so I thought tonight I would
talk a little bit about what my job is
like a day to day as the communication
sort of
a media person and a little bit about
how the environment in City Council and
city hall has changed dramatically since
I started working in City Hall way back
in 2012 compared to now and why and then
I thought you know Derek and I were
talking a little earlier today and I
thought maybe we could look at a kind of
an example or a case study of a big
fight that we just had in City Council
which is the fight around regulating
rideshare companies thought that might
be something that's of a lot of
relevance to the folks in this space and
then I'll take your questions so my job
as the communications person for elected
officials or for the Progressive Caucus
in particular is I'm the person who
helps figure out how do we talk about
what we're doing anytime you see a
politician on TV talking or standing
behind a podium and having a press
conference there's a me behind the
scenes that helped make that happen and
help to figure out down to the minor
details so what is the shot that we want
the cameras to pick up what's behind the
person or who's behind the person is
there an image on the screen or no image
on the screen is there stuff and repeat
is there a visual aid is there a crowd
of activists or community members what
are the talking points what's this what
it what is the most simple way to
communicate the core message what are we
trying to do here that's my job as the
behind-the-scenes person making that
happen I'm also the person who like make
sure there's a microphone and a podium
and does lots of unspectacular things
like that but without those things we
wouldn't be able to make sure people
could hear us so it matters so that's
the simplest way to talk about what I do
when a press release goes out often I'm
the one who wrote it and hit Send
there's a lot of more nuanced stuff
involving relationships so often I'm I
spend a lot of my day just talking to
people on the phone or in person talking
to reporters having coffee with
reporters and setting up issues
explaining the backstory on a
policy fight that's coming up explaining
what the dynamics are in terms of the
relationships between the aldermen and
the sponsors of any piece of legislation
sometimes it's as simple as explaining
how the process really works so for a
piece of legislation to pass someone has
to introduce it someone has to sponsor
it then it has to get sent to a
committee meeting then there's a the
committee meeting happens and there's a
vote then they'll either passes or fails
then it goes to the full City Council
sometimes it's about me laying that sort
of basic stuff out for a given a
reporter or a group of reporters so
that's sort of the background on what my
job is and then there's also the part
about helping 11 different elected
officials get on the same page and make
sure that they're all singing from the
same song sheet that can be a really
hard job sometimes so that's that's part
of it too when the Progressive Caucus
was first formed in the early years of
the manual administration when there
were eight members it was very much seen
as an anti Rahm Emanuel opposition bloc
the situation was very polarized in City
Hall to the to the degree that I would
say members of the Progressive Caucus
were almost seen as pariahs they rarely
were able to get legislation passed they
spent a lot more time on defense trying
to stop bad things from happening or
stop bitching say bad things trying to
stop policies from passing that we saw
as harmful to the city's neighborhoods
and regular folks working families it
was difficult to build alliances with
people who weren't in the Progressive
Caucus a reason being that a lot of
aldermen who weren't in the Progressive
Caucus we're pretty much sticking to the
to the mayor's office as their main
source of support and security there
there the conventional wisdom is you
stick with the mayor you'll be all right
you'll get reelected and you can keep
keep coasting on through that has
changed how many people I know a lot of
people are from Skokie and evanston but
how many people actually voted in the
2015 municipal elections actually that's
not bad it was it was a big one
I was it was an incredibly significant
election and a lot changed not just at
the not just as the mayoral level but I
would say more significantly at the city

p.span: council level many of the alderman who

div.p: were most inclined to stick with the
stick with the administration no matter
what whether it was right or wrong
whether they agreed with the issue or
not a lot of those people lost their
seats even though there was a
Chicago Ford that was designed to
protect them and designed to take out
members of the Progressive Caucus
there's been lots reported on about that

p.span: if anybody wants to look it up so the

div.p: message coming the lesson coming out of
that election was everybody who
demonstrated some independence and some
tendency to think for themselves and do
what's right for the people got
reelected and though many of the ones
who didn't did not including lots of
people who seemed invincible who seemed
like incredibly powerful people who'd

p.span: been in for decades had tons of money in

div.p: the bank lost their seats sometimes a
sort of upstart or almost lost our seats
some of them cut their seats but just by
the skin of their teeth to just sort of
upstart progressive grassroots
candidates so that really changed the
tenor and City Council in this new term
many aldermen are much more inclined to
demonstrate that they're thinking for
themselves and taking action
independently to compound that to make
to make that even more extreme I think
that there were two other factors one
was the largest property tax increase in
Chicago's history which happened last
November and yes in the fall David
November oh thank you that it passed
many many members of the City Council
voted to make it happen but they also
recognize that with that vote came a lot
of vulnerability and that that created
even more pressure for some of those
to demonstrate some independence to take
some independent votes and to you know
be more willing to work with progressive
alderman be more willing to work with
progressive allies and think more
proactively about introducing
legislation to demonstrate to their
constituents that they're actually
trying to get some stuff done for them
and then there's the third the third
factor which I'm sure everyone in this
room is aware of that changed that that
changed the dynamics in City Council
which is the sort of the after the
release of the loop on McDonald video
and the aftermath of that of that you
know what happened as a result every

p.span: alderman and city council feels the

div.p: impact of that I would say and I think
the administration has been rocked to
its core as a result I don't think most
people would dispute that at this point
and so what we've seen that was november
24th or so so pretty soon after the woo
that's a good that was that was that was
dramatic so all of us to say those three
factors the the results of the election
the property tax increase the historic
property tax increase the results of the
laQuan McDonald video have drastically
changed the environment in City Council
and where we find ourselves now is in a
place where there are many new
opportunities to really move progressive
policy ideas through the City Council
and some are some are passing and some
are not but the legislative process is
happening in a way that I've never seen
it before and that it certainly wasn't
when I started working in City Hall so a
couple of examples of that in the last
couple of months or just this this last
City Council meeting jun 22nd we passed
an ordinance and when I say we I mean
the Progressive Caucus but also many
alderman who aren't in the Progressive
Caucus because it passed unanimously
passed an ordinance that will guarantee
paid sick time off to four hundred and
sixty thousand workers in Chicago that's
undisputedly going to make life better
for a lot of people that's the kind of
progressive policy that the progress of
caucus champions and that other aldermen
are more
more also working together to get done
we recently passed and and I keep
referring I keep like looking at this

recently passed an ordinance called the
you're going to help to help me debt

transparency accountability and

and accountability anytime the city gets

know it's not super sexy but it's a

might be find that more sexy though so
we're getting stuff done in a way that I
don't think we would have been able to
I'm positive we would not have been able

didn't get done which is the the

Department and all that kind of stuff so

they're the idea that there can be

to my mind and this I don't think is a
